columns.text: This exercise requires us to determine how the change in tax law affected ex-dividend stock prices.

Changes in stock price is an important element used for analyzing the profitability of the company's investment. Ex-dividend price is an important element that the investors follow when valuing the stock price. When the tax law changes, the actual ex-dividend stock price of the company is also affected. The ex-dividend stock price falls as the tax law changes in this scenario.
This exercise will determine the effect of changes in tax law to the ex-dividend stock prices.

### KEY TERMS

* **Dividends** - refers to the resources earned by the entity that is paid out to its shareholders. This may be in the form of cash, property, or stocks.

* **Ex-dividend date** - the ex-dividend date is usually a day before the date of record. On this date, the issuing entity determines who will be entitled to receive the dividends checks. When the investor acquires stocks before the ex-dividend date, he will be entitled to receive the returns. When the investor acquires shares on or after the ex-dividend date, he will not receive any dividend checks, and entitlement will go to the previous owners of the stocks. **No journal entry will be made on this date.**

The selling price on and after the ex-dividend date will be computed as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{SP after ex-dividend date} &= \text{SP before ex-dividend date} - {\text{Dividends $-$ Taxes}}\\
\end{aligned}$$
*SP stands for selling price.*

The selling price of stocks on and after the ex-dividend date will be reduced by the amount of declared dividends and the amount of taxes to be paid. The taxes to be paid are those imposed by the government whenever the shareholders received their share on the dividends.

To summarize, the lower the rate imposed on the dividends will lead to a lower stock price per share on and after the ex-dividend date. On the other hand, the higher the rate imposed on dividends will indicate otherwise.
